fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A model M of an algebraic theory T is an interpretation of the signature \Sigma _T which validates all the equations E_T. That is, for each equations x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l = r in E_T, we have: [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l]_M = [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid r]_M We refer to a model of T as a T\text {-algebra} or T\text {-model}.
Notes about algebraic effects and handlers.
In algebra we study mathematical structures that are equipped with operations satisfying equational laws.

A signature \Sigma is a collection of operation symbols with arities \{(\text {op}_i, \text {ar}_i)\}_i. The operation symbols opi may be any anything, but are usually thought of as syntactic entities, while arities \text {ar}_i are non-negative integers. An operation symbol whose arity is 0 is called a constant or a nullary symbol. Operation symbols with arities 1, 2 and 3 are referred to as unary, binary, and ternary, respectively.

A list of distinct variables x_1, \cdots , c_k is called a context. The \Sigma \text {-terms} in this context are built inductively using the following rules:
Each variable x_i is a \Sigma \text {-term} in this context
If t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i} are \Sigma \text {-terms} in this context, then \text {op}_i(t_1, \cdots , t_{\text {ar}_i}) is a \Sigma \text {-term} in this context We write x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid t to indicate that t is a \Sigma \text {-term} in the context x_1, \cdots , x_k. A closed \Sigma \text {-term} is a term in the empty context.
A \Sigma \text {-equation} is a pair of \Sigma \text {-terms} l and r in the context x_1, \cdots , x_k: x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l = r We shall often elide the context and write simply l = r.
An algebraic (equational) theory T = (\Sigma _T, E_T) is given by a signature \Sigma _T and a collection \Epsilon _T of equations over the terms of this signature.

Let \Sigma be a signature, an interpretation I of \Sigma is given by the following data:
A set |I| called the carrier of the interpretation
For each operation symbol \text {op}_i, a map [\text {op}_i]_I : |I|^i \to |I| The bracket []_I here is called the semantic bracket and is typically used when syntactic entities (operation symbols, terms, equations) are mapped to their mathematical counterparts.

The interpretation can be extended to terms and equations. A \Sigma \text {-term} t in the context x_1, \cdots , x_k is interpreted as a function [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid t]_I : |I|^k \to |I| as follows:
The variable x_i is interpreted as the i-th projection [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid x_i]_I : |I|^k \to |I|, \quad (a_1, \cdots , a_k) \mapsto a_i
A compound term in context x_1, \cdots , x_k is interpreted as the composition of the semantic brackets of the operation symbols and the terms: |I|^k \xrightarrow {[t_1]_I, \cdots , [t_{\text {ar}_i}]_I} |I|^{\text {ar}_i} \xrightarrow {[\text {op}_i]_I} |I|

A model M of an algebraic theory T is an interpretation of the signature \Sigma _T which validates all the equations E_T. That is, for each equations x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l = r in E_T, we have: [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid l]_M = [x_1, \cdots , x_k \mid r]_M We refer to a model of T as a T\text {-algebra} or T\text {-model}.

Let M and N be models of an algebraic theory T. A model homomorphism from M to N is a function f:|M|\to |N| that preserves the interpretation of the operations of T. That is, for each operation symbol f\in \Sigma _T, we have: f_N \circ (f, \cdots , f) = f \circ f_M where f_M and f_N are the interpretations of f in M and N respectively. We say that f is a model isomorphism if it is bijective. We say that M and N are isomorphic if there exists a model isomorphism between them.
We may organize the models of an algebraic theory T into a category \mathscr {Mod}(T) whose objects are the models of the theory and the morphisms are the model homomorphisms.

So far we have considered the models of an algebraic theory as sets with operations. More generally we can consider models in any category C with finite products. Hence the definition of an interpretation and a model may be directly transcribed.

An interpretation I in C is given by
An object |I| in C, called the carrier
For each operation symbol \text {op}_i, a morphism in C [\text {op}_i]_I : |I|^i \to |I| Notice that a nullary symbol is interpreted as a morphism |I|^0 \to |I|, which is a morphism form the terminal object 1\to |I| in C.

Similarly, the interpretation can be extended to terms and equations in the same way. A model of an algebraic theory T in C is an interpretation M of its signature \Sigma _T which validates all the equations E_T. The definition of a homomorphism is now the morphism in the category C. The T\text {-models} and T\text {-homomorphisms} in C form another category, denoted by \mathscr {Mod}_C(T).
Of special interest are the free models of an algebraic theory.

Let T be an algebraic theory and X be a set, the free T-model, also called the free T-algebra, generated by X is a model M together with a map \eta :X\to |M| such that for any T-model L and every map f:X\to |L|, there is a unique T-homomorphism \bar {f}:M\to L such that the following diagram commutes:
